IRS990.ActivityOrMissionDesc: Our work focuses on improving the health and academic success of children and youth by advancing health services in schools.
IRS990.MissionDesc: The California School-Based Health Alliance is at the forefront of the movement to put health care where kids are, in schools.
IRS990.Desc: CSHA provides technical assistance to help schools and communities set up and sustain school health centers and school-based health programs, including new tools and resources. We also managed special projects and learning collaboratives focusing on mental health, peer mentoring, tobacco use prevention, and substance abuse screening. Our conference, webinars, tool kits, and technical assistance help SBHCs offer high-quality, age-appropriate care to students and families. Accomplishments include: - Increasing the number of SBHCs in California from 300 to over 400. Today approximately 300,000 K-12 California students attend school on a campus with a school-based health center.- Hosting our annual Conference in April 2023 with 500 registered attendees.- Participating as a core partner in the California Community School Partnership Program, helping local education agencies across the state develop a deeper understanding of the pivotal role of school-based health program integration.- Releasing the updated Vision to Reality 2.0, which is used as the blue print for school-based health stakeholders and practitioners to start, enhance and/or expand SBHCs.

ProgSrvcAccomActy2Grp.Desc: CSHA conducts outreach to build support for the SBHC model and to generate interest among schools and communities in addressing health, mental health, and wellness at their school sites. Accomplishments include:- Re-Launched the Central Valley School Health Coalition for education and health providers focused on starting/enhancing SBHCs in the Central Valley.- Led a growing network of school-health stakeholders including more than 8,000 individuals representing SBHCs, school districts, community health centers, dental and mental health providers, policy groups, and others concerned with children's health.- Continued with the SBHC Provider cohort, which includes a diverse group of school health champions from across California.

ProgSrvcAccomActy3Grp.Desc: CSHA Advocates for policies that improve access to high-quality care for children and youth by making SBHCs an integral part of the health care and education systems. In 2023, we successfully sponsored a California Assembly bill to support the definition, scope of practice, and state funding formula for School-Based Health Centers in California. We also conducted advocacy with local, state, and federal legislators to support school health and school-based health services. In addition, we produced a few different reports and toolkits to support the field by strengthening school health services.

SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The Internal Revenue Service and the California Franchise Tax Board have determined that the Organization is exempt from federal and state income taxes under IRC 501(c)(3) and California RTC 23701(d). The Organization has evaluated its current tax positions as of June 30, 2023 and is not aware of any significant uncertain tax positions for which a reserve would be necessary. The Organizations tax returns are generally subject to examination by federal and state taxing authorities for three and four years, respectively, after they are filed.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, Line 11b
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: Form 990 is reviewed by the Executive Director and then presented to the Board of Directors prior to filing with the IRS.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, Line 12c
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: CSHA's conflict of interest policy states that an interested person must disclose an actual or possible conflict of interest and be given the opportunity to disclose all material facts to the directors and members of any committee considering the proposed arrangement. That committee then meets privately to determine whether a conflict of interest exists, appointing a disinterested person if needed to investigate alternatives. After exercising reasonable due diligence, the board of directors considers whether CSHA can obtain a more advantageous arrangement without a conflict of interest. The board then votes without the interested party present on the best course of action and the majority determines the outcome. If this process is not reasonably practical, a committee can make this determination in good faith and consistent with these standards. Each director reviews and annually signs an acknowledgment of CSHA's conflict of interest policy and is asked to disclose any conflicts.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, Line 15a
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The board of directors will review any compensation arrangement of the director of CSHA, and will approve the compensation arrangement in advance of payment only after determining that the compensation is just and reasonable. The board of directors will take into account the written evaluation of the director where the board and staff provide feedback, as well as considering the organization budget and salary adjustments recommended for staff. The board will document the basis for its determination concurrently with making the determination.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, Line 15b
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The process to determine all other compensation increases are included in the annual budget presentation which the board reviews, changes, approves.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section C, Line 19
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: CSHA makes its governing documents, conflict of interest policy and financial statements available to the public upon request.
